summary: This is an FBI internal request form from the Miami Division to the Records Management Division and Special Technologies and Applications Office, requesting scanning, automation, and data formatting assistance for telephone records related to the obstruction of justice case against Alfredo Rodriguez. The document reveals Rodriguez, former house manager for Jeffrey Epstein, attempted to sell an address book believed to contain contact information for additional underage victims.

persons.name: Alfredo Rodriguez
persons.role: Former house manager and butler to Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Subject of an FBI obstruction of justice case opened in October 2009. He came into possession of an address book believed to contain names and numbers of additional underage victims of Epstein and attempted to sell it.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Subject of a child prostitution case
persons.context: Referred to as the subject of a child prostitution case. His former house manager, Alfredo Rodriguez, possessed an address book believed to contain information on Epstein's additional underage victims.

connections.description: Rodriguez was the former house manager and butler to Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: FBI opens obstruction case against Rodriguez
events.description: Miami Division opened an obstruction of justice case against Alfredo Rodriguez.

events.title: Start date for telephone record review period
events.description: The document notes a review period for telephone records from September 1, 2001, to the present.

locations: Winchester, Virginia 22602 (DocLab - Telephone Application Audit Processing Team address)
keyFacts: Alfredo Rodriguez, Jeffrey Epstein's former house manager, was the subject of an FBI obstruction of justice case for attempting to sell an address book believed to contain names and numbers of additional, previously unknown underage victims of Epstein.
The FBI was processing telephone records (target number 340-771-1523) obtained from the address book, which were believed to belong to Epstein, his associates, or potential underage victims.
The document is an internal FBI request for technical assistance (scanning, automation, data formatting) to load these records into the Telephone Application (TA) repository for investigative use.

The address book came into Rodriguez's possession during his employment with Epstein, and he attempted to sell it to an Undercover Employee (UCE) instead of complying with federal subpoenas from pending civil litigation.
